tit.cmt: *統一用語リストの里山（Satoyama) の訳語：outskirt of country, farming landscape near the hills and mountains in Japanは、下記の本項の定義と一致しない部分があるので、使用しませんでした。

sen.j: 里山（さとやま）とは、集落、人里に接した山、あるいはこうした地形において人間の影響を受けた生態系が存在している状態を指す言葉である。
sen.e: Satoyama is a word referring to the state in which there exists an ecosystem influenced by the human beings in the hills and mountains adjacent to a settlement or habitations, or in a similar geographical conditions.

Satoyama is a word referring to the state in which there exists an ecosystem that is influenced by peoples in the hills and mountains adjacent to a settlement or habitat, or similar geographical conditions.

Satoyama is a word referring to the state in which there exists an ecosystem that is influenced by peoples in the hills and mountains adjacent to a settlement or habitat, or similar geographical conditions.

sen.j: 文献上、最初に「里山」という単語が現れるのは1759年6月に尾張藩が作成した「木曽御材木方」という文書においてである。
sen.e: Its first appearance in an academic material was in June 1759, in a document titled "Kiso Onzaimoku-Kata" (Kiso-style Lodging) (木曽御材木方)compiled by the domain of Owari.
sen.cmt: 「木曽御材木方」 →定訳・正しい読み方不明です："Kiso Onzaimoku-Kata" (Kiso-style Lodging) (木曽御材木方) としました。

sen.j: これによると里山とは「村里家居近き山をさして里山と申候」と定義されるものである。
sen.e: In this document, Satoyama was defined as 'satoyama means a mountain close to habitations in a rural settlement.'

sen.e: On the other hand, it can be said that Tsunahide SHIDEI, who was a teacher at the Faculty of Agriculture, Kyoto University and Kyoto Prefectural University among others, was the person who defused the concept of Satoyama through his speech and writing activities that lead to the present reevaluation of Satoyama.

sen.j: 日本列島において、継続的に人間の手が入る森林が出現した時期は、少なくとも縄文時代までは遡ることが出来る。
sen.e: The period in which the forests began to be intervened by the constant human activities in the Japanese archipelago can be dated back, at least, to the Jomon Era.
Human activity first began to be seen in the forests of the Japanese archipelago to at least, to the Jomon Era.
The first forest where continuous human activity can be seen in Japanese archipelago dates back at least to the Jomon period.

sen.j: 三内丸山遺跡の研究によって、この遺跡に起居していた縄文人集団が近隣の森に栽培種のクリやウルシを植えて利用していたことが明らかとなっている。
sen.e: Thanks to the study on Sannai-Maruyama site, it was revealed that a group of people called Jomons living in this site, cultivated chestnut and acquer trees in the woods close to their settlement and made use of these plants.

sen.j: しかし歴史時代に入るとともに日本列島の里山は乱伐と保護を繰り返していくこととなる。
sen.e: However, in historic times, Satoyama in the Japanese archipelago underwent repeated cycles of destructive exploitation and protection.
During this prehistoric era, Satoyama in the Japanese archipelago underwent repeated cycles of destructive exploitation and protection.

sen.j: 最初に里山のオーバーユースによる森林破壊が顕在化したのは畿内であり、日本書紀によると、天武天皇の6年（676年）には南淵山、細川山などで木を伐採することを禁じる勅令が出されている。
sen.e: The forestry destruction by the overuse of Satoyama became obvious in Kinai (the five provinces surrounding the ancient capital of Nara and Kyoto), and according to "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan), an imperial edict to prohibit logging in the mountains such as Mount Minamibuchi and Mount Hosokawa, was issued.

The destruction caused by the over-forestation of Satoyama became obvious in Kinai (the five provinces surrounding the ancient capital of Nara and Kyoto), and according to "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan), an imperial edict to prohibit logging in the mountains such as Mount Minamibuchi and Mount Hosokawa, was issued.

sen.cmt: destructionの前にfirstを挿入しました。In 676を追加しました。

sen.j: だが日本列島における森林破壊は進行し、800年代までには畿内の森林の相当部分が、また1000年頃までには四国の森林も失われ、1550年代までにこの二つの地域の森林を中心にして日本列島全体の25％の森林が失われたと考えられている。
sen.e: However, the destruction of forests had advanced, and it is thought that by the year 800, a considerable part of the forests in Kinai had been lost, and by around the year of 1000, the destruction had been extended to the forests of Shikoku region and by the 1550's, 25% of the forests in the whole Japanese archipelago had been lost.

However, the destruction of forests had advanced, and it is thought that by the year 800, a considerable part of the forests in Kinai had been lost, and by around the year of 1000, the destruction had been extended to the forests of Shikoku region and by the 1550's, 25% of the forests in the whole Japanese archipelago had been lost.

However, the destruction of forests had advanced, and it is thought that by the year 800, a considerable part of the forests in Kinai had been lost, and by around the year of 1000, the destruction had been extended to the forests of Shikoku region and by the 1550's, 25% of the forests in the whole Japanese archipelago had been lost.

sen.j: 織豊政権期、江戸時代に入っても日本列島の森林破壊は留まる所を知らず、1710年までには本州、四国、九州、北海道南部の森林のうち当時の技術で伐採出来るものの大半は失われた。
sen.e: During the administrations of Nobunaga ODA and Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI (Azuchi Period and Monoyama Period (1568 - 1600)) as well as during in the Edo Period (1603-1868), the destruction of forests did not stop, and in Honshu (main island), Shikoku, Kyushu and southern Hokkaido regions, the major part of the forest exploitable with the technology available at that time had been lost.
sen.cmt: 織豊政権期→the administrations of Nobunaga ODA and Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI (Azuchi Period and Monoyama Period (1568 - 1600))と期間の西暦を入れました。
sen.e: During the administrations of Nobunaga ODA and Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI (Azuchi Period and Monoyama Period (1568 - 1600)) as well as during in the Edo Period (1603-1868), the destruction of forests did not stop, and in Honshu (main island), Shikoku, Kyushu and southern Hokkaido regions, the major part of the forest exploitable by the technology available at that time had been lost.

During the administrations of Nobunaga ODA and Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI (Azuchi Period and Momoyama Period (1568 - 1600)) as well as during in the Edo Period (1603-1868), the destruction of forests did not stop, and in Honshu (main island), Shikoku, Kyushu and southern Hokkaido regions, the major part of the forest exploitable by the technology available at that time had been lost.

sen.j: こうした激烈な森林破壊の背景には日本列島の人口の急激な膨張による建材需要や、大規模な寺社・城郭の造営が相次いだことがあったと考えられている。
sen.e: This drastic destruction was accounted for by an increased demand for construction materials owing to a nationwide population explosion and the constructions of large-scale temples, shrines and castles that were carried out successively.

This drastic destruction was accounted for by an increased demand for construction materials owing to a nationwide population explosion and the large-scale construction of temples, shrines and castles that were carried out successively.

This drastic destruction was accounted for by an increased demand for construction materials owing to a nationwide population explosion and the large-scale construction of temples, shrines and castles that were carried out successively.

sen.j: すなわち、18世紀にまで日本列島の里山は継続的に過剰利用の状態にあった（「はげ山」参照）のであり、「持続可能な」利用が為されていたわけではない。
sen.e: This means that until the 18th century, the Satoyamas in Japanese archipelago had been constantly overused (please refer to the section 'Hageyama' (treeless hill)), and Satoyama had not been used in a 'sustainable' manner.

This means that until the 18th century, the Satoyamas in the Japanese archipelago had undergone constant overforestation. (please refer to the section 'Hageyama' (treeless hill)), and Satoyama had not been used in a 'sustainable' manner.

sen.cmt: overforestationの後ろのピリオドをとりました。overforestationをover forestationに変更しました。

sen.j: こうした広範な森林破壊は木材供給の逼迫をもたらしただけでなく、山林火災の増加、台風被害の激甚化、河川氾濫の増加など様々な災厄を日本列島にもたらすことになった。
sen.e: Such an extensive forest destruction not only caused an scares supply of timber, but also triggered various disasters in the Japanese archipelago, including increased wildfires, intensified damages by typhoons, and frequent floods of rivers.

Such an extensive forest destruction not only threatened the supply of timber, but also triggered various disasters in the Japanese archipelago, including increased wildfires, intensified damage by typhoons, and frequent river flooding.

Such an extensive forest destruction not only threatened the supply of timber, but also triggered various disasters in the Japanese archipelago, including increased wildfires, intensified damage by typhoons, and frequent river flooding.

sen.j: このような状況を憂慮した徳川幕府は1666年以降、森林保護政策に乗りだし、森林資源の回復促進と厳格な伐採規制・流通規制をしいた。
sen.e: Worried about such a situation, the Tokugawa shogunate decided to adopt a forest protection policy, and launched an initiative to recover and promote forest resources, setting up strict regulations of logging and distribution.

Worried about the situation, the Tokugawa shogunate decided to adopt a forest protection policy, and launched an initiative to recover and promote forest resources, setting up strict regulations towards logging and distribution.

sen.j: こうした対策の結果、日本列島の森林資源は回復に転じ、里山の持続可能な利用が実現した。
sen.e: As a result of such measures, the forest resources in Japan started to be recovered gradually and the sustainable use of Satoyama became possible.
As a result of such measures, the forest resources in Japan gradually recovered, enabling the sustained logging of Satoyama.
As a result of such measures, the forest resources in Japan gradually recovered, enabling the sustained logging of Satoyama.

sen.j: だが、近世の持続可能な里山利用は近代に入ると3度の危機に瀕した。
sen.e: However, the sustainable usage of satoyama was threatened three times in recent times.
However, this sustained state of Satoyama was threatened three times within recent memory.

sen.j: 最初の危機は明治維新前後で、旧体制の瓦解とともに木材の盗伐・乱伐が横行し、里山の森林が急激に失われた。
sen.e: The first crisis took place in the pre- and post-Meiji Restoration periods, when the forest of Satoyama had been rapidly lost due to the widespread timber piracy and destructive logging, which broke out with the collapse of the old system.

sen.j: その後、社会の安定とともに里山の植生は一定の回復を見たものの、太平洋戦争が始まり物資が欠乏すると再び過度の伐採が行われ、各地に禿げ山が出現した。
sen.e: Afterwards, the vegetation of Satoyama was recovered at one time as the society was going to be stabilized, but when the Pacific War (World War II) broke out, Satoyama again underwent excessive logging due to the lack of materials, and many of hills and mountains were left treeless around the country.
sen.cmt: 太平洋戦争→Pacific War (World War II) としました。

sen.j: 戦中・戦後の乱伐からの回復は、1950年に始まる国土緑化運動の成果を待たなければならなかった。

sen.j: 人間の関与が失われたことによる植生の変化（極相林化や孟宗竹の侵入による竹林化）、不法投棄される粗大ゴミや産業廃棄物による汚染にさらされている。

sen.j: 製塩は大量の燃料を必要とする（年間通して操業する場合、塩田の面積の75倍の広さの森林を全て燃料として1年で消費しなければならない）為、製塩業にとって塩木山の確保は死活問題であった。
sen.e: For salt production, a great volume of fuel is required (in case of consecutive operation of salt production during a year, as fuel it is necessary to consume an entire forest 75 times larger in extension than the salt field itself as fuel), and therefore, for salt manufacturers, it was a life-and-death matter to secure a Shokkiyama (塩木山).

sen.e: This way of fuel supply for salt production had continued until the early 19th century when coal began to be commonly used, and the scarceness of the forest resources caused by excessive exploitation, which that was carried out completely ignoring the forest reproduction speed, sometimes provoked conflicts.

sen.e: In recent times, since dried grass was an important manure for paddy cultivation, in order to secure the necessary amount of dried grass, sometimes a small-scale Kusayama was prepared and kept free from regeneration of trees.

sen.e: In addition to the usages mentioned above, according to Takashi UCHIYAMA, in the times before the Showa Period, there were impoverished families who had thoroughly recovered their livelihood, after several years' retired stay in Satoyama, by carrying a self-sufficient life during several years and completely suppressing cash disbursement (they are supposed to be the cases in Ueno Village, Gunma Prefecture).

tit.j: 里山の管理・所有体制
tit.e: Management and ownership system of Satoyama
Management and ownership system of Satoyama
Management and ownership system of Satoyama

sen.j: 江戸期の里山は国家（将軍家や藩）が所有し民間の利用を認めないもの（御建山などと呼ばれる）、土地は民間所有（入会地形態）であっても木材は国家所有で伐採には国家の許可が必要なもの（御留山や御用木と呼ばれる）、土地も木材も民間所有（入会地形態）で木材伐採にも官許の不要なもの、個人所有のもの、宗教施設所有で当該宗教施設の為に用いられるものなど多様であった。
sen.e: There were various types of Satoyama in the Edo Period: those that were owned by the government (Shogun family or domains) and excluded the use of general citizens (called Otateyama, etc); those whose land was a privately-owned property (form of iriaichi (common land)) but trees were state-owned assets and required a government's permission for lodging (called Otomeyama or Goyoboku); those whose land as well as trees were privately-owned and did not required any official permission for logging (form of iriai); those which are individually-owned; and those which were owned by religious organizations and used to construct their religious facilities.

There were various types of Satoyama in the Edo Period: those that were owned by the government (Shogun family or domains) and excluded from use by general citizens (called Otateyama, etc); those which were privately-owned (form of iriaichi (common land)) but trees were state-owned assets and required the government's permission for logging (called Otomeyama or Goyoboku); those whose land as well as trees were privately-owned and did not required any official permission for logging (form of iriai); those which were individually-owned; and those which were owned by religious organizations and used to construct their religious facilities.

There were various types of Satoyama in the Edo Period: those that were owned by the government (Shogun family or domains) and excluded from use by general citizens (called Otateyama, etc); those which were privately-owned (form of iriaichi (common land)) but trees were state-owned assets and required the government's permission for logging (called Otomeyama or Goyoboku); those whose land as well as trees were privately-owned and did not required any official permission for logging (form of iriai); those which were individually-owned; and those which were owned by religious organizations and used to construct their religious facilities.

sen.j: このうち御留山を民間の材木商や村が伐採する場合には藩に現銀による対価を支払わねばならなかった。
sen.e: In case of the trees of Otomeyama, the timber merchant or village that wanted to cut the trees had to pay the price in silver currency to the owner domain.

sen.j: また民間所有の里山であっても国家に税金（山年貢などと呼ばれる）を支払うことが多かった。
sen.e: And in many cases, even though they were privately-owned, they were subject to duty (called yamanengu (mountain tax), etc.).
And in many cases, even though they were privately-owned, they were subject to duties (called yamanengu (mountain tax), etc.).

sen.j: 前述のように近世、特に石炭が燃料として普及する以前の日本列島における里山の負荷は一貫して高く、村落共同体は里山の植生崩壊を防止する為に様々な規則を作って対応した。
sen.e: As mentioned before, Satoyama's burden had been heavy in the Japanese archipelago during all through the time until the extension of coal as a fuel began, and to cope with such a burden, each community set up its own regulations to protect the destruction of Satoyama's vegetation.

As mentioned before, the stress on Satoyamas throughout the Japanese archipelago had been heavy during until coal began to be used as a fule, and to cope with this burden, each community set up its own regulations to protect the destruction of Satoyama's vegetation.

sen.cmt: duringを除きました。fuleをfuelに変更しました。

sen.j: これらの規則は「村掟」「村定」「村規則」などと呼ばれ、里山を入会地として持つ村であればほぼ確実にこの種の規則を文書として備えていた。
sen.e: These rules were called 「Muraokite (village rules)」「Murasadame (village statute)」「Murakisoku (village regulations)」, and almost all the villages had this kind of rules in a written form, as far as they had Satoyama as their common land.

sen.e: These rules were called 「Muraokite (village rules)」「Murasadame (village statute)」「Murakisoku (village regulations)」, and almost all villages had a written ruleset, as far as they had Satoyama as their common land.

These rules were called 'Muraokite (village rules)', 'Murasadame (village statute)', 'Murakisoku (village regulations)', and almost all villages had a written set rules, as far as they had Satoyama as their common land.
sen.cmt: 「」を' 'に変更し、,を挿入しました。rulesetをset rulesに変更しました。

sen.j: 村掟によって定められる里山の利用規則は極めて詳細かつ厳密なものであった。
sen.e: Usage rules stated in Muraokite were precisely and strictly articulated. For example, it was common that the volume of grass allowed to cut for manure was fixed to each household, and the mowing period (called Kuchiake (start)) was strictly set up in many villages.

Usage rules stated in Muraokite were precisely and strictly articulated. For example, it was common that the volume of grass allowed to be cut for manure was fixed to each household, and the mowing period (called Kuchiake (start)) was strictly set up in many villages.

sen.j: 例えば肥料用の草は刈り取って良い量が家ごとに決められていることも珍しくなかったし、刈り取って良い時期が厳密に設定されている（「口開け」と呼ばれる）ことも多かった。
sen.e: For example, it was common that the volume of grass allowed to be cut for manure was fixed to each household, and the mowing period (called Kuchiake (start)) was strictly set up in many villages.

sen.j: 村掟を破った者への制裁も予め決められており、多くは米や銀による科料の支払い＋盗伐分の返還が科されていた。
sen.e: The sanctions to the person who violated Muraokite were also determined, and in many of the cases, the violator was obliged to pay back in silver the amount of fines plus the value corresponding to the volume he stole.
The penalty for people that violated the Muraokite were also determined, and in many of the cases, the violator was obliged to pay fines in silver plus the value corresponding to the volume he stole.

sen.j: またこれらの他に労働奉仕も科される例や、盗伐者が科料を払えない場合の五人組による連帯責任による科料支払いが決められている例もある。
sen.e: There were also other cases, in which the violator was obliged to render a service, or if the violator was not able to pay the fines, the Gonin-gumi system (a collective responsibility system based on a neighborhood group composed of 5 persons), to which he belonged, had to assume the collective responsibility to pay the fines.

sen.j: 特に住民の数に対して利用可能な里山が少ない地域では、里山の管理は厳重なものであり、許可されていない場合は草を一掴み刈り取ったり、木の枝を一本折るだけでも罰せられる場合すらあった。
sen.e: Especially, in the areas that had few Satoyama in proportion to the number of habitants, the management of Satoyama was extremely strict and even a bunch of grass or a branch of tree was not allowed to carry off without permission, and those who broke the rule were sometimes subject to even punishment.

Especially in areas that had few Satoyama in proportion to the number of habitants, the management of Satoyama was extremely strict and not so much as a bunch of grass or tree banch was allowed to be carried off without permission, and those who broke the rule were sometimes subject to fair punishment.

Especially in areas that had few Satoyama in proportion to the number of habitants, the management of Satoyama was extremely strict and not so much as a bunch of grass or tree branch was allowed to be carried off without permission, and those who broke the rule were sometimes subject to fair punishment.

sen.j: 夜間の盗伐を防ぐ為に持ち回りで里山の夜番をしていた村もあったほどである。
sen.e: There were villages which kept night watch rotation to prevent the robbing in Satoyama during the evening,
There were villages which kept a night watch rotation to prevent the robbing of Satoyama during the evening,
There were villages which kept a night watch rotation to prevent the robbing of Satoyama during the evening,

sen.j: それだけ厳重な管理をしても里山の盗伐は頻発し、また村々入会の里山では、里山を巡っての村と村の間での対立も続出した（山論と呼ばれる）。
sen.e: Even under such a strict control, illegal logging in Satoyama frequently occurred, and when the form of Satoyama was Muramura iriai (common land of plural villages), it was jointly used by the residents of more than one village as a common land, however, these villages often had confrontation over Satoyama (the dispute was called sanron (mountain dispute)).

Even under such strict controls, illegal logging in Satoyama frequently occurred, and when the form of Satoyama was Muramura iriai (common land of plural villages), it was jointly used by the residents of more than one village as a piece of common land, however, these villages often had confrontations over Satoyama (the dispute was called sanron (mountain dispute)).

Even under such strict controls, illegal logging in Satoyama frequently occurred, and when the form of Satoyama was Muramura iriai (common land of plural villages), it was jointly used by the residents of more than one village as a piece of common land, however, these villages often had confrontations over Satoyama (the dispute was called sanron (mountain dispute)).

sen.j: このように近世の里山とは決して村落共同体と自然が調和したユートピア的空間などではなく、国家や村落共同体が厳重な管理体制を敷かなければオーバーユースによるカタストロフに直結するような場だったのである。
sen.e: In reality, Satoyama in recent times was far from the utopian space where the communities enjoyed a harmonious coexistence with the nature, but the space that would have directly run into a catastrophe by overuse, unless the state or a community would not have prevented it by establishing a rigid control system.

In reality, Satoyama in recent times was far from the utopian space where ommunities enjoyed a harmonious coexistence with nature, but a space that would have been met with catastrophe by overuse, unless the state or community had not have prevented it by establishing a rigid control system.

In reality, Satoyama in recent times was far from the utopian space where communities enjoyed a harmonious coexistence with nature, but a space that would have been met with catastrophe by overuse, unless the state or community had not have prevented it by establishing a rigid control system.

sen.j: 明治期以降、里山は国有林となるか、あるいは細切れに分割されて個人所有となる、自治体に所有されるといった所有形態に移行した。
sen.e: Since entering the Meiji Period, the form of Satoyama's ownership started to be changed, and they were shifted to state-owned forests, individually-owned estates after they were fragmented, or municipal-owned forests.

Since entering the Meiji Period, the form of Satoyama's ownership started to change, and they were shifted to state-owned forests, individually-owned estates after they were fragmented, or municipal-owned forests.

Since entering the Meiji Period, the form of Satoyama's ownership started to change, and they were shifted to state-owned forests, individually-owned estates after they were fragmented, or municipal-owned forests.

sen.j: 明治政府の地租改正作業の中で、入会地が入会権を持つ諸個人の私有地に分割され、入会地ではなくなっていくこともあったし、また入会地であることの証明が無ければ官有地とするという明治政府の政策により、数多くの入会地としての里山が官有地として召し上げられたと考えられている。
sen.e: It is probable that in the process of the land-tax reform carried out by the Meiji government, some of iriaichi (the common lands) had lost their function and had been divided into privately-owned lands with the right to access, and many of them were expropriated under the policy of the Meiji government, which promoted the registration of these ands as public lands if they had no proof of common lands.

sen.j: 歴史を遡ると、近世までに日本の里山の大半はアカマツ林、あるいは草山、禿げ山となっていた。
sen.e: Tracking back the history, the major part of Japanese Satoyama had been converted into red pine forests, or Kusayama (pasture grounds) and treeless hills by the modern ages.

sen.j: 本来の植生は木材や薪の切り出しによって失われ、落ち葉や草の類も田畑の肥料として搬出されてしまった為に土壌の栄養分が乏しくなり、痩せた土地でも生きられるアカマツが優勢となってしまったのである。
sen.e: The autochthonous habitat was lost due to the exploitation of timber and firewood, and the removal of fallen leaves and underbrush used for the farmland manure impoverished the soil depriving it of nutrition, and allowed the dominant propagation of red pine trees that are resistant in poor soils.

sen.e: Moreover, as the red pine was a handy species and had a lot of usages in Japanese modern agriculture, the people selectively planted them.

sen.j: まとめると、歴史的に見て日本列島の里山は植生が極度に破壊された禿げ山、草山、アカマツ林から、本来の極相とは違う形で安定した二次林、あるいは竹害的な竹林、そしてその土地本来の極相林など、多様な植生が存在する場所であるということが言える。
sen.e: In summary, Satoyama in the Japanese archipelago can be defined historically as a place where we can observe diversified habitats, such as bald mountains, grass mountains and red pine forests which are the results of extreme destructions, secondary forests which are stabilized in a form different from the inherent climax vegetation, or bamboo forests as a result of harmful bamboo invasion, and lastly, the local autochthonous climax forests.

sen.j: このなかには「荒れた雑木林」という新しい概念が導入されている。
sen.e: In this idea a new concept of 'devastated copse' is introduced.

sen.j: ただ、20世紀後半以降は里山は完全に放置される場合が多く、本来の極相に戻りつつある地域も多い。
sen.e: However, since the latter 20th century, a large number of Satoyama have been left completely free from the human control, and in many regions they are recovering their autochthonous climax vegetations.

sen.j: 有岡はこのような状況を評して、弥生式農耕の開始以降、平成期ほど里山が樹木に覆い尽くされている時代は無かったと指摘している。
sen.e: Arioka qualifies such a situation and points out that since the beginning of the Yayoi style agriculture, there has been no period like the Heisei Period in which Satoyama is so densely covered by trees.
